awd_titl_txt: NeTS: Small:  Collaborative Research:  BRICK:  Breaking the I/O and Computation Bottlenecks in Massive MIMO Base Stations
awd_abstract_narration:
Massive multi-antenna (MIMO) wireless systems, in which the base-station is equipped with hundreds or thousands of antenna elements, will enable unprecedented data rates, cell coverage, and transmission reliability compared to that of existing cellular communication systems. The presence of hundreds or thousands of radio-frequency (RF) transceivers and antennas, however, results in excessively high internal data rates, which results in chip-interconnect and computation bottlenecks that prevent a straightforward deployment of this technology in practice. This project will develop new technologies that rely on decentralized signal processing at the base-station in order to avoid these bottlenecks, which leads to feasible and scalable solutions that enable base-station designs with thousands of antenna elements without sacrificing performance or reliability. In addition to enabling massive MIMO in practice, the project will advance future cellular networks through collaboration with the telecommunications industry, with the Argos massive MIMO testbed, and other network research testbeds. The project's broader impact on education and outreach will include multiple components, including (i) training a diverse group of students as part of a collaborative, multi-institutional research team in the areas of communication theory and circuit design, (ii) integrating outcomes of the work into undergraduate and graduate courses, and (iii) making research outcomes broadly available through public-domain software packages and open-education resources via OpenStax courseware.

The project develops novel decentralized algorithms as well as very-large scale integration (VLSI) and general-purpose computing on graphics processing units (GPGPU) architectures based on antenna clustering and parallelization, for the uplink (users communicate to base-station) and the downlink (base-station communicates to users). The main idea of decentralized baseband processing is to divide the signal-processing workload at the base-station into multiple computing fabrics that are each connected to only a subset of RF transceivers and antennas. To reduce the chip-interconnect and computation bottlenecks the project investigates (i) optimization-based algorithms that exchange consensus information among the antenna clusters and (ii) message-passing-based algorithms that avoid such consensus exchange altogether. The most promising algorithm solutions will be implemented on field-programmable gate array and GPGPU clusters to assess the efficacy and limits of the developed solutions with real-world performance, hardware, and bandwidth constraints. The results of this analysis will provide guidelines that enable optimal massive MIMO base-station designs that use decentralized baseband processing.

por.por_cntn:
General Summary

Multiple antenna wireless basestation design seeks to improve data rates and reduce interference to multiple users. Systems with hundreds of antennas and the associated power amplifiers and analog to digital converters are being developed. However, there is an input/output (I/O) bottleneck where the radio frequency (RF) front end connects to the digital computer that executes the baseband signal processing to transmit and receive multiple users' data. In this project we partitioned the hundreds of antennas and their RF electronics into smaller clusters on the order of 16 or 32 antenna modules to simplify this I/O bottleneck. In this decentralized baseband processing, each of these clusters does local computations and then shares and exchanges this intermediate data with the other clusters to form a complete basestation design. Algorithm simulation and verification was performed on a parallel processing system with multiple graphics processing unit (GPU) accelerator boards with each GPU performing computations for a cluster.

 

Intellectual Merit

In this project several decentralized baseband processing architectures were developed for both the uplink and downlink for a large scale or Massive MIMO multiple user wireless basestation. The baseband processing considered algorithms for uplink multiple user detection and downlink multiple user beamforming. In the downlink, power amplifier nonlinearities were also considered along with effects on beamforming and spurious out of band emissions. Digital predistortion (DPD) algorithms which are associated with baseband processing were also included. Since decentralized baseband processing partitions the overall problem into clusters, an important result includes methods for combining intermediate results. The message passing and feedforward algorithms developed in this project balance the tradeoffs of data exchange, computational complexity, and bit error rate communication performance. When also considering algorithms for transmitter power amplifier nonlinearity, the traditional complexity bottleneck of algorithms with a DPD function per antenna at the final output stage were compared with our method for DPD per user stream. For small numbers of multiple users moving the DPD function before the downlink precoder while modifying the guard band OFDM subcarriers results in complexity reduction and reduces out of band spurious emissions similar to traditional methods.

 

Broader Impacts

This project trained both graduate and undergraduate students in wireless communications algorithms, computer architecture, network interfaces, hardware accelerators, and machine learning. The graduate students also led project teams in our ongoing multi-year Vertically Integrated Projects (VIP) research program at Rice. The VIP team called Parallel Hardware Applications in Science and Technology (PHAST) focuses on 5G wireless communications and includes freshman through graduate students in STEM. There has also been project coordination with scientists and engineers developing wireless infrastructure at Samsung, Xilinx, and Nvidia. Technology transfer discussions with industry have focused on our distributed baseband processing and the interface among system components and the radio frequency power amplifiers. Multiple publications in conferences and journals have described the research results and a Massive MIMO simulator called MIMOSA has been made available on Github.
